comment.author: 7770342@N02
comment._content: The fly posters on the scaffold wall behind are fascinating.

comment.author: 24329363@N00
comment._content:
The Victorians didn't like a street being called 'petticoat' so they changed the name of the street to middlesex Street. However, it never caught on and the street is still known as Petticoat Lane.
Like the photo above, the street is still a place for stall holders to sell their goods.

comment.author: 92943860@N00
comment._content: The fly posters give an indication of the vibrant Jewish culture of east London in the early 20 Century. In the early 1980s I used to teach art to geriatrics in hospital in east London, most of whom were Jewish and remembered this time well. Fascinating. You may be interested in reading about the (Royal) Pavillion Theatre in Whitechapel (as advertised on the posters) : www.arthurlloyd.co.uk/PavilionTheatreAndWonderlandWhitech...

comment.author: 47310289@N05
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called AuthenticLondon, and we'd love to have this added to the group! Hello, I am a former GEH student, I was studying at the Selznick School. I am developing a blog on traditional London businesses (markets, shops, artisans...) would love to have my picture on my group (which I have just started...). Thank you very much and greetings to Rochester Flavia De Facendis
